utterances: Bird Runningwater is associate director of the Native American and Indigenous Initiatives for the Sundance Film Festival.
From NPR News, it's DAY TO DAY.
For all you flyers out there, a welcome choice may be on the way.
A new low fare airline is on the tarmac.
It's Virgin America, and it plans to operate out of San Francisco.
But the man behind the discount airline, famed British entrepreneur Richard Branson, is not so welcome, at least by the U.S.
government.
The feds require that domestic airlines not have foreign ownership and Virgin has had to adapt.
MARKETPLACE's Steve Tripoli is here to tell us more.
Hi, Steve.
Hi, John.
Ok, first, tell us about what we'd be getting with Virgin America.
I hope it's those backrubs.
I had one when I flew across the Atlantic.
It was great.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Well, I don't know about the backrubs.

The routes aren't officially announced yet, but it looks like Virgin America will offer flights to at least the east coast, southern California, and Las Vegas - out of San Francisco, supposedly starting this summer.
And as you said, it adds another low fare airline to compete with the likes of JetBlue and Southwest, backrubs or no.
There's a lot of chatter about how this deal might - how Virgin might reshape the U.S.
airline market.
Could that really happen?
I mean, haven't Southwest and JetBlue and those kind of airlines already done that?
Well, John, the jury's out and the airline competition, as you know, is famously cutthroat.
So we'll have to see how competitors respond.
But industry consultant Michael Boyd, of the Boyd Group in Colorado, thinks Virgin America's not going to shake up many of its competitors.
We just don't see a market vacuum for Virgin America.
There just isn't one there.
Any place they want to go out of San Francisco, they're going to have a lot of competition already and very good competition.
But what about this foreign ownership question?
We all know - the big backer's Richard Branson of Virgin Airways.
He's British.
How is that resolved?
Well, one analyst I spoke with joked that they threw the chief executive of Virgin America under the bus to resolve it.
And that's figuratively true.
Fred Reid, the chief executive has to step down as part of yesterday's deal, even though he's American.
The Department of Transportation reasoned that since he was hired by Branson, he might be, quote, unquote, beholden to foreign interests.
And Branson's company had to also give up its board seat on Virgin America and they had to put their ownership of parent company shares under a U.S.
trustee.
I don't really understand this, though.
We don't ban foreign ownership of banks, car factories, I guess, even supermarket chains.
Why are airlines any different?

Well, Michael Boyd, the consultant, says the rationale is that airlines are, in fact, different because they're an increasingly crucial part of national transportation infrastructure so they're vital in ways that banks and supermarkets aren't.
And his example is the hypothetical foreign ownership take over of United Airlines.
Do they really care about whether Reno has service?
Do they really care whether Chicago has service?

And the argument could be made their objectives would not be to serve the United States, so much it might be to drain United Airlines, if they got a hold of it, to fly to China or something like that.
Now, the counterarguments are that this violates free trade principles and that it's really reflecting the desire of U.S.
airlines to shut out competitors, but that's for another day.
Thanks, Steve.
Steve Tripoli of public radio's daily business show MARKETPLACE.
It's produced by American Public Media.
(Soundbite of music)
DAY TO DAY returns in a moment.

She reads some names.

Retired Israeli general Yaakov Amidror.

So slowly slowly begin to be kind of bodies market in which we didn't give back the bodies of killed terrorists, expecting if they get one of our bodies we will have enough to pay for that not by releasing a live terrorist but by giving them back bodies.
Israeli politicians can face pressure from Israeli families to not release Palestinian remains if their own loved ones are missing.
Zehava Shaul's son Oron is believed to have been killed in Gaza in 2014, but no corpse was recovered.
She watched Israel return Palestinian bodies now with sorrow.
(Through interpreter) All of their dead the army returns.
And I ask what about our children?
Where are they in this deal?
And in Gaza, a Palestinian mother, Ibtisam al-Aghawani, is waiting for the body of her son.
She says Israel has held his remains since he participated in a suicide attack almost eight years ago.
(Through interpreter) It is like a fire inside that my son is not buried near me.
To keep a dead body, why?
It is bones now.
Both these parents - Israeli and Palestinian - say all they can do is wait.
Emily Harris, NPR News.
So other news.
Fans of Kate Bush have been waiting for a chance to see her go on tour.
They've been waiting in fact for more than a generation, since 1979.
Now the British singer-songwriter is performing her first live shows in 35 years - all shows in London.
And Christopher Werth reports that fans are coming from around the world.
She was the first woman to top the British charts with a self-written song.
(SOUNDBITE OF KATE BUSH SONG, ""WUTHERING HEIGHTS"")
The year was 1978.
Kate Bush was 19 years old.
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""WUTHERING HEIGHTS"")
(Singing) Out on the wily, windy moors, we'd roll and fall in green.
Since then she's hit the U.K.
Top 40, 25 times, without touring to support her recordings.
And now that she is back on stage, eight of her old albums are back on the charts.
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""WUTHERING HEIGHTS"")
(Singing) It's me, your Cathy, I've come home.
Kate Bush's impressive vocal range and complex lyrics have earned her a legion of dedicated followers, many of whom are traveling great distances to see her.
I'm Duncan Reith.
I've come from Toronto, Canada.
I met Reith and his wife, Beth, under a glowing marquee outside the Hammersmith Apollo theater in London.
All 22 shows here sold out in less than 15 minutes, and Reith happened to be among the lucky few to get tickets.
You never thought this was going to happen, and the fact that it has means you've got to do whatever it takes to be here.
